lede.lede: Despite a rocky beginning, the current hospitalization and new admissions metrics from the HHS Protect public dataset have stabilized—and they’re now largely harmonious with state-reported hospitalization metrics if we account for differences in data definitions and reporting lag time.

blog_post.title: Introducing the COVID Tracking Project City Dataset

lede.lede: Our new data collection tracks the spread of COVID-19 in 65 cities and counties across the United States, and it lets us see how fatality rates vary widely across geographies.

blog_post.title: Visualizing COVID-19’s Impact on Hospitals Across the Country

lede.lede: The HHS released a facility-level data set on COVID-19 hospitalizations in December. We’ve taken that data and created an interactive map, allowing the public to see how their local hospitals are faring against this virus.

blog_post.title: All Eyes on Hospitalizations: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 30

lede.lede: Holiday reporting has garbled most metrics. Going by current COVID-19 hospitalizations, outbreaks in the Midwest are still easing, but every other region is in trouble.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Hannah Hoffman is a data entry and data quality shift lead at The COVID Tracking Project and a student in the Washington, DC area.

blog_post.title: How We Source Our Data and Why It Matters

lede.lede: States provide COVID-19 data in a variety of sources and formats. To ensure our data is as accurate and consistent as possible, we spend a lot of time looking at these sources to make sure that we’re capturing the most data possible for each state, while maintaining high standards of data quality and integrity. Today, we’re publicly releasing a detailed set of notes on the sources of all our data points.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Catherine Pollack is a third year PhD candidate in the Quantitative Biomedical Sciences program at Dartmouth College. Her dissertation research combines data science, epidemiology, and public policy to combat online health misinformation.
Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Current, New, and Cumulative Hospitalizations: What They Are and Why They Matter

lede.lede: COVID-19 hospitalizations continue to rise across the country, but the method in which they are reported can take several different forms. We dive into the meaning of some of the most common metrics and comment on why some may be more interpretable than others.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Dave Luo has an MD/MBA and is a Data Science and Data Viz lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Rebecca Glassman has a Master’s in Public Health and is a public health researcher in academia. Opinions expressed are her own.
Betsy Ladyzhets is a Research Editor at Stacker and works on data quality and the COVID Racial Data Tracker at the COVID Tracking Project.

Catherine Pollack is a third year PhD candidate in the Quantitative Biomedical Sciences program at Dartmouth College. Her dissertation research combines data science, epidemiology, and public policy to combat online health misinformation.

blog_post.title: New HHS dataset tells us precisely where COVID-19 is hitting hospitals

lede.lede: The Department of Health and Human Services released a new public dataset on December 7 that includes data down to the facility level on where COVID-19 patients are hospitalized and how healthcare systems are coping. We explored how to use this dataset and what patterns it can reveal.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: Cases Matter

lede.lede: As COVID-19 cases rise across the United States, claims are circulating that case increases are (mostly or entirely) due to expanded testing, and do not indicate a spike in infections. The data does not support this conclusion.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.
Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.
Joseph Bensimon is a member of the COVID Tracking Project’s Data Quality team.

blog_post.title: As North Dakota’s Deaths Metrics Diverge, We’re Switching to a Less Backlogged Measure of Fatalities

lede.lede: North Dakota's growing backlog of death certificates means its count of individuals who died due to COVID is no longer an accurate measure of deaths in the state. As a result, we're switching our metric to deaths among cases, matching the state’s most prominent method of reporting.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: Daily COVID-19 Data Is About to Get Weird

lede.lede: The upcoming holiday means that many COVID-19 metrics are going to drop—and then rise—in ways that may trip up unsuspecting observers. Here’s what to watch out for.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Alexis C. Madrigal is a staff writer at The Atlantic, a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the author of Powering the Dream: The History and Promise of Green Technology.
Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.

blog_post.title: COVID-19 Hospitalizations Have Hit an All-Time High

lede.lede: More people are now in the hospital with COVID-19 than ever before, and the per-capita hospitalization rates in the Midwest have now surpassed those of the South in the summer’s Sunbelt surge. Hospitals across the country are warning of staff and PPE shortages, and case rates continue to spike in every US region.

childMarkdownRemark.html: The COVID Tracking Project is a volunteer organization launched from The Atlantic and dedicated to collecting and publishing the data required to understand the COVID-19 outbreak in the United States.

blog_post.title: COVID-19 Deaths Are Rising, But Fatality Rates Have Improved

lede.lede: As COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations once again rise across the United States so, inevitably, will deaths. But there is reason to hope that we will not see the devastating fatality rates of the initial spring surge.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Quang P. Nguyen is a PhD candidate in the Department of Epidemiology at Dartmouth College.
Kara Schechtman is Data Quality Co-Lead for The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Confirmed and Probable COVID-19 Deaths, Counted Two Ways

lede.lede: We're up to 24 states publishing both confirmed and probable COVID-19 deaths, and we're adding those data points into our API. But states are also using two different ways of deciding which deaths to count as COVID-19 deaths.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Is There a Right Way to Chart COVID-19 Deaths Over Time?

lede.lede: States across the US use two primary methods for announcing COVID-19 deaths: date of death (reported) and date of death (actual). To analyze how the pandemic is trending across the country, understanding the relationship between these two data points is crucial. Here's what we've learned from investigating both methods in three of our largest hotspots: Arizona, Florida, and Texas.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Sara Simon works on The COVID Tracking Project’s data quality team and is also a contributing writer. She most recently worked as an investigative data reporter at Spotlight PA and software engineer at The New York Times.

blog_post.title: Why The COVID Tracking Project’s Death Count Hasn’t Hit 200,000

lede.lede: Several sites tracking the progression of the virus hit a grim milestone today: more than 200,000 deaths since the pandemic began. Our figures haven’t yet reached that level. Here’s why.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Testing In Limbo, Hospitalizations and Deaths Still Dropping: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 10

lede.lede: A long holiday weekend makes ambiguous testing data even harder to understand, but hospitalizations are dropping, which is good.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Joanna Pearlstein is an editorial lead at the Covid Tracking Project and a former editor at WIRED and Protocol.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Holiday Reporting Lags Interrupt Positive Trends: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 17

lede.lede: Though cases are rising in parts of the Midwest, hospitalizations in the West and South continued trending downward. The Labor Day holiday impacted data reporting lag times both this week and last, obscuring what had been positive trends in September.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Finally, Some Good News. This Week in COVID-19 Data, Aug 20

lede.lede: Key data points in our COVID-19 tracking are finally beginning to trend positively. In the South, tests rose while cases fell, a pattern not seen there since early spring. Hospitalizations fell for the third week straight, but deaths remained above 1,000 a day on average.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Rebecca Glassman has a Master’s in Public Health and is a public health researcher in academia. Opinions expressed are her own.
Betsy Ladyzhets is a Research Editor at Stacker and works on data quality and the COVID Racial Data Tracker at the COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: Hospitalization Data Reported by the HHS vs. the States: Jumps, Drops, and Other Unexplained Phenomena

lede.lede: In mid-July the federal government began requiring hospitals to report COVID-19 data to the HHS rather than to the CDC. We compared current hospitalization data reported by the federal government and state health departments since the switch, and found contradictions that suggest the federal data continue to be unreliable, while the state datasets face their own challenges.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Erin Kissane is a co-founder of the COVID Tracking Project, and the project’s managing editor.
Robinson Meyer is a co-founder of The COVID Tracking Project and a staff writer at The Atlantic.
Peter Walker is Head of Marketing & Growth at PublicRelay and Data Viz Co-Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.

blog_post.title: What’s Going on with COVID-19 Hospitalization Data?

lede.lede: Data for current COVID-19 hospitalizations in the United States—one of our most valuable metrics for understanding the pandemic and its effects—has become highly erratic in recent weeks. Here's what we've learned from watching the data closely, and from our initial analysis of the hospitalization data being published by the federal government.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Jessica Malaty Rivera has an MS in Emerging Infectious Diseases and is the Science Communication Lead at The COVID Tracking Project.
Alice Goldfarb leads The COVID Tracking Project’s part in The COVID Racial Data Tracker, and is a Nieman Visiting Fellow.

blog_post.title: Record New Cases, Surging Hospitalizations, Rising Deaths: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 9

lede.lede: The South continues to be the epicenter of surges in both cases and hospitalizations. In Arizona, Florida, South Carolina, and Texas, COVID-19 deaths have begun to climb following jumps in new cases. And for the first time since April, deaths are rising nationally.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Whet Moser is a freelance writer in Chicago.
Conor Kelly is the director of data analytics at Hanover Research.

blog_post.title: To Understand the US Pandemic, We Need Hospitalization Data—and We Almost Have It

lede.lede: Hospitalization data can help us understand the severity of COVID-19 outbreaks in the United States, and even see a little bit of what's to come. Until very recently, we didn't have a national summary figure—now we can finally piece together a national statistic from states that provide it, and estimate the rest.

childMarkdownRemark.html: Whet Moser is a freelance writer in Chicago.

blog_post.title: Why Changing COVID-19 Demographics in the US Make Death Trends Harder to Understand

lede.lede: COVID-19 death data lags behind testing data in ways we mostly understand. What we only partly understand is how an infection rate that seems to be skewing younger will affect the death toll in surging regional outbreaks.

While the CDC COVID Data Tracker closely tracks the current death counts compiled from states by The COVID Tracking Project—which are well-suited to supporting rapid pandemic response—NCHS’s death certificate data more closely aligns with gold standard definitions for cause of death used in epidemiological studies, standardized across states. However, the data provides a less timely picture of COVID-19 deaths. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"What’s in the CDC COVID Data Tracker deaths data","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-2"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The primary difference between these two datasets is their source.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The data on the CDC COVID Data Tracker is sourced directly from states, which submit updated deaths counts to the CDC each day. As the data is sourced from each state, it very closely matches the information reported on state COVID-19 dashboards—and the COVID Tracking Project’s data for each state. This makes the data a convenient replacement for COVID Tracking Project data. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"However, the CDC COVID Data Tracker comes with an important caveat—one familiar to users of COVID Tracking Project data: It isn’t standardized across all states. States make many choices about what to submit to the CDC, from whether they submit confirmed and probable death breakdowns to how they define “confirmed” and “probable.” This means, just like state data, the counts won’t all be comparable across states—even though it’s coming from the federal government. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"To date, 33 jurisdictions are reporting both confirmed and probable deaths to the CDC, 3 are reporting just confirmed deaths, and 24 are reporting only a figure for “total deaths,” which appears to include both probable and confirmed deaths. Even among states providing a breakdown of confirmed and probable deaths, different definitions exist. For example, Michigan appears to count a patient who dies with a positive result for COVID-19 via antigen test as a confirmed death, but Georgia would count this as a probable death.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"What’s in the NCHS deaths data","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-2"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The NCHS dataset is based on death certificates from the National Vital Statistics System (NVSS) submitted by states under the National Vital Statistics Cooperative Program that have passed quality control procedures. As such, NCHS data represents data that aligns with how researchers define cause of death in epidemiological studies, standardized across jurisdictions. The NHCS ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/nvss/vsrg/vsrg03-508.pdf"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"officially counts","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" a death as attributed to COVID-19 when it is listed either as an ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"underlying cause of death","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" (Part I of a ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/dvs/death11-03final-acc.pdf"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"death certificate","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":") or ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"contributing to the cause of death","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" (Part II of a death certificate). Because there can be a substantial lag between when a death occurs and when a certificate is submitted to and reviewed by the NCHS, the NCHS notes that its data is provisional, and more recent dates should be interpreted with caution as a likely undercount. Because death certificates need to be processed before they can be included in the NCHS data, NCHS notes the most recent two weeks of data are unstable: ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"46KYHYM6gUz0gMBwJmLFKM","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"This difference in sources contribute to differences in how each agency’s data matches up with that of The COVID Tracking Project. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"In general, data from the CDC COVID Data Tracker almost perfectly matches state data, but is not standardized across jurisdictions. On the other hand, NCHS data does not exactly match state data, but definitions are comparable across state lines. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Federal COVID-19 Death Datasets","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-4"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"25i4DaV1JPQ8zAIBS6Kr2U","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"It is important to note that ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"neither dataset provides the definitive truth","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" about the number of deaths associated with COVID-19. Each dataset is subject to delays and likely undercounts the true number of COVID-19 deaths. The CDC COVID Data Tracker reflects issues around data collecting pipelines that state departments of health have been experiencing. On the other hand, data from NCHS is likely impacted by ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.inquirer.com/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-covid19-cause-death-certificate-pcom-20200401.html"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"mistakes in the death certifying process","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", and the overall delays resulting from manual review—delays that can vary by state, making comparisons of recent data between states tricky even though definitions are standardized across state lines.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Because of these delays, both datasets are subject to revisions as states identify additional COVID-19 deaths and the federal government reviews and classifies death certificates. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"How to use the data","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-2"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Both datasets share the same data apparatus operated by the CDC. This allows both datasets to be available through the agency’s website, as well as sharing a common API (application programming interface) infrastructure for automated querying. As such, accessing the datasets is a simple process for data users familiar with federal datasets.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"CDC COVID Data Tracker","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"3reWBt7sddbIIvVLSLfUL8","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The CDC COVID Data Tracker’s central dataset on fatalities, ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://data.cdc.gov/Case-Surveillance/United-States-COVID-19-Cases-and-Deaths-by-State-o/9mfq-cb36"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"United States COVID-19 Cases and Deaths by State Over Time","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", is updated daily and provides information from 60 jurisdictions: the 50 states, D.C., 8 territories (American Samoa, Federated States of Micronesia, Guam, Northern Mariana Islands, Puerto Rico, Palau, Republic of Marshall Islands, and the Virgin Islands), and information from New York City, which is reported separately from NY state. It includes six categories of information reported on deaths, though not all are reported for every jurisdiction: ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"the total number of confirmed deaths","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"the total number of probable deaths","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"the number of new deaths since last update","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"the number of new probable deaths since last update","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"the total number of deaths, which sums both new and historic deaths","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"and a field specifying whether this “total death” figure includes a state’s probable deaths in the count.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"unordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Here’s a look at how this dataset’s categories compare to CTP’s:","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"5YPyKqlUUzRAKYgMvEp8O","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"It is worth noting that there are several states which have data reported for “new probable deaths” but no information given for “probable deaths” over time: Arkansas, Florida, Iowa, Kansas, Pennsylvania, New Hampshire, and West Virginia. Based on correspondence with state health officials, we believe this problem originates from crossed wires about sharing permissions between states and the federal government. (See our ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covidtracking.com/analysis-updates/federal-covid-data-101-working-with-case-data"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Federal Case Data 101 post","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" for additional information.) ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"In addition to its main dataset, the CDC COVID Data Tracker provides data tables with ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#demographics"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"demographic breakdowns","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" of fatality information by race and ethnicity, age, and sex. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"NCHS data","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-3"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"6i0K7IlF2GQhOdU65mOrDa","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-block"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The NCHS data provides multiple associated data tables, of which a list can be accessed via an ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/covid19/covid-19-mortality-data-files.htm"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"index page","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". These data tables include fatality counts broken down by various demographic factors such as age, sex, race and ethnicity, etc. Additionally, the NCHS provides other specialized measures of mortality such as total deaths from all causes (also known as all-cause mortality), excess deaths estimations, and fatalities coded as due to pneumonia or influenza. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Most data tables provided by NCHS are ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"updated weekly","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", with the exception of the overall data table, titled ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://data.cdc.gov/NCHS/Provisional-COVID-19-Death-Counts-by-Week-Ending-D/r8kw-7aab"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"provisional COVID-19 deaths by week","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":", which ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"updates daily","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" but counts","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":" are still aggregated by week","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". Each data table can be accessed either through direct download from the CDC data portal or with the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://dev.socrata.com/foundry/data.cdc.gov/r8kw-7aab"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Socrata Open Data API","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":".  ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The NCHS data comes with robust documentation on the data tabulation procedure. Each data table mentioned has its own page, with detailed caveats and explainers. Sections on “","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/covid-19.htm#understanding-the-numbers"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Understanding the Numbers","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"” and “","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/covid-19.htm#understanding-death-data-quality"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Understanding Death Certificate Data","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"” give users information about how provisional counts are tabulated, as well as the different quality issues with regards to the death certificates pipeline. More information can be found in the sections “","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/vsrr/covid19/tech_notes.htm"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Technical Notes","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"” as well as the ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/covid19/faq.htm"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"FAQ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":".","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Due to differences in sourcing, users of data from The COVID Tracking Project should be aware of the following: ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"NCHS does not require laboratory confirmation to count a death as due to COVID-19; factors such as clinical presentation can bear on the classification. Likewise, an individual may die with a positive COVID-19 test but not be counted by NCHS if COVID-19 did not contribute to their death.","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"target":{"sys":{"id":"2uH7ytmyGxsjVLZ8pLyMFM","type":"Link","linkType":"Entry"}}},"content":[],"nodeType":"embedded-entry-inline"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"The terms “confirmed” and “probable” used in ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/vsrr/covid19/tech_notes.htm"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"NCHS communications","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" refer to how COVID-19 is listed on the death certificates, not to the COVID-19 case ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://cdn.ymaws.com/www.cste.org/resource/resmgr/ps/positionstatement2020/Interim-20-ID-02_COVID-19.pdf"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"definition","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" provided by the Council of State and Territorial Epidemiologists.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Data from NCHS are labeled as “provisional” due to delays in the process of submitting a death certificate. More details can be found in the “","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/vsrr/covid19/tech_notes.htm"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Technical Notes","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"” section on the NCHS website. As such, data should be considered delayed, and prior data will be adjusted accordingly when new certificates are processed. The agency suggests that the difference might be within the time-scale of 1-2 weeks.  ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Data is organized by ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"date of death","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" while data from The COVID Tracking Project reflects death by ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"date of reporting. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Unlike COVID Tracking Project data, historical NCHS data does not exhibit a “death lag” due to reporting.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"list-item"}],"nodeType":"unordered-list"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"How to make federal death data better","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"heading-2"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"These two datasets provide a multi-faceted look at US deaths associated with COVID-19. ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"bold"}],"value":"Even in their current state, these datasets are valuable, but we think they can be even better and more helpful to a wider range of data users. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"First, we recommend that documentation of both datasets be complete and centralized. The CDC COVID Data Tracker includes a note stating that definitions of confirmed and probable deaths are “standardized,” but we believe they can’t be, since they so closely match the very ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"unstandardized","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" confirmed and probable totals that states report. The CDC Tracker team should document how each state defines the confirmed and probable COVID-19 deaths it counts. Documentation explaining the deaths reported in the CDC COVID Data Tracker are also spread across multiple parts of the agency’s website, including footnotes on the bottom of its ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#cases_casesper100klast7days"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Cases and Deaths by State","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" page, on its ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/covid-data/faq-surveillance.html"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"FAQ page","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":",","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":" and in its daily ","nodeType":"text"},{"data":{"uri":"https://beta.healthdata.gov/dataset/COVID-19-Community-Profile-Report/gqxm-d9w9"},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"underline"}],"value":"Community Profile Report","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"hyperlink"},{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":". We recommend that this documentation be compiled in a central location.  ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"NCHS deaths data is more clearly explained—for this dataset, we recommend only that documentation be more centralized and clearly labeled. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Second, we would like to suggest that  the CDC publish a brief introduction to the two datasets, including the differences between them, and the contexts in which one is more useful or appropriate than the other. This would help non-specialists find information more quickly and help prevent confusion when users encounter both datasets at the same time. ","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"Our suggestions focus on delivering helpful, detailed documentation on the nuances of these datasets because we believe that thorough explanations enhance trust in this vital information.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[],"value":"","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"},{"data":{},"content":[{"data":{},"marks":[{"type":"italic"}],"value":"Additional research and contributions from Dave Luo and Peter Walker.","nodeType":"text"}],"nodeType":"paragraph"}],"nodeType":"document"}

references.caption: Comparing death counts from The COVID Tracking Project, CDC COVID Data Tracker, and NCHS. Counts are aggregated by week ending date as defined by NCHS.

image.title: Comparing CTP, CDC, NCHS weekly deaths from COVID-19, Jun 6, 2020–Jan 30, 2020
image.description: Comparison graph of US total death data from the NCHS, CDC COVID Data Tracker, and The COVID Tracking Project. Data from the CDC COVID Data Tracker almost perfectly matches COVID Tracking Project data, while the NCHS data follows the general trend but does not perfectly align. The NCHS data exhibits a taper because of the lag time in processing death certificates.

table.table:
|                   | CDC COVID Data Tracker                                        | NCHS                                                      | 
|-------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------|
| Source            | States reporting daily updates on deaths directly to the CDC  | Analysis of death certificates sent by states to the NVSS |
| Update frequency  | Daily                                                         | Daily                                                     |
| Time interval     | Daily                                                         | By MMWR week                                              |
| Dating method     | Date of report                                                | Date of death                                             |
| Location of death | Varies - residency, place of death                            | Place of death                                            |
| Standardized definitions  | No. Varies by jurisdiction                            | Yes                                                       |

image.title: How to download data from the CDC's COVID Data Tracker
image.description: A GIF demonstrates how to download the underlying data of the CDC COVID Data Tracker. The deaths data can be downloaded from the "Cases & Deaths" section of the tracker. At the bottom of the page, a button reads "View Historic Case and Death Data." Clicking this button leads to an API page where the data can be exported. This dataset is also linked in the blog post.

table.table:
| CDC Description                                                                              | CDC Column Name | CTP API Field Name |
|----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------|--------------------|
| Date of counts                                                                               | `submission_date` | `date`               |
| Date and time record was created                                                             | `created_at`      | `lastUpdatedEt`      |
| Total number of cases                                                                        | `tot_cases`       | `positive`           |
| Total confirmed cases                                                                        | `conf_cases`      | `positiveCasesViral` |
| Total probable cases                                                                         | `prob_cases`      | `probableCases `     |
| Number of new cases                                                                          | `new_case`        | `positiveIncrease`*  |
| Number of new probable cases                                                                 | `pnew_case`       | N/A                |
| Total number of deaths                                                                       | `tot_death`       | `death`              |
| Total number of confirmed deaths                                                             | `conf_death`      | `deathConfirmed`     |
| Total number of probable deaths                                                              | `prob_death`      | `deathProbable`      |
| Number of new deaths                                                                         | `new_death`       | `deathIncrease`*    |
| Number of new probable deaths                                                                | `pnew_death`      | N/A                |
| Jurisdiction                                                                                 | `state`           | `state`              |
| If Agree, then confirmed and probable cases are included. If Not Agree, only total cases.    | `consent_cases`   | N/A                |
| If Agree, then confirmed and probable deaths are included. If Not Agree, only total deeaths. | `pnew_death`      | N/A

references.caption: \* `positiveIncrease` and `death increase` represent the difference from previous day topline metrics rather than actual new cases/deaths on a given day

image.title: How to download NCHS provisional death data
image.description: A GIF shows how to download NCHS provisional death data. On the index page for the dataset, clicking the link "Provisional COVID-19 Death Counts By Week Ending Date and State" leads to a page from which the data can be exported.

footnote.footnote: Even though counting such deaths is theoretically possible in state reports, states regularly revise and re-examine deaths data. While revisions can occur due to accidentally counting non-COVID deaths, the number of mistakes is usually small.

lede.lede: The CDC provides two different datasets regarding COVID-19 fatalities. Here’s a walkthrough of how they compare to each other and to The COVID Tracking Project’s data.
